html:
6.23.18  6:54 pm   6.22.18  9:34 am   is that the longest question you've ever got or answered?


embedded answer: https://billwurtz.com/questions/q.php?date=201806220934

6.22.18  9:34 am   Do you agree with this analysis of "hello sexy pants"?

"This whole masterpiece is a analysis of late stage capitalism and its unnability to satisfy the alienated consumer it produce in the very negation of its production.

What is the "pants" ? It's the commodified product par excellence, by owning the pants, you don't only own an object, you wear it and thus you make the object a part of your own identity, while you objectify yourself in the processus : at the end, the pants own you. That's how love work between humans, but that's also how it's manufactured in our spectacular society. As Baudrillard said "seduction represent mastery over the symbolic universe while power represents only mastery over the real universe"

"Where'd you get those pants ?" said the cash cow : someone finally said that the king is naked. Indeed, where did those pants come from ? Isn't it the product of a bengali kid ? More deeply here relies a critiq ue of commodity fetishism : alienation make us forgot that we, as humans, are the producers of this pants; and just like the african tribes who forgot that they were the creators of their fetish, our production became our new god. No response to the quiet scream of the cow, just "hello", again and again. "I wanna know why it hurts so bad" : The ignorance of this alienation brings pain, we feel depossessed without understanding why, and when we see the pants we need to possess it badly by the act of consumption, since we don't feel that we own it by the act of production. We even have the feeling that the pants can "make a wish come true" : that's the final stage of the fetishised entity put above our heads. "Hello sexy pants did you know that I like your pants ?" : The commodity has become more than just pants.

And in Congress all the boys get mad, and not because they oppose capitalism, bill wurtz is more subtile : the politicians are mad because they loose control over the system, they no longer have a word to say in the direction, just like everyone, they become simple executant of the will of the Capital.

While nature is out there, represented by the squirrels, all we can see is the omnipresent modern propaganda of the media, in this TV everything looks fine and nice, there is happy faces everywhere and it tells us to be friends, but in reality it's divising humans, humans are no longer "friends", they are actors in the representation of a friendship mediated by the society of the spectacle, in wich being a friend is just a question of posture, of "friendly stance".

And then the capital tell you that thanks to him you can go all around the world, and indeed it became "easy as 1, 2" to go through the hills of France : tourism - human circulation packaged for consumption, a by-product of the circulation of commodities - is the opportunity to go and see what has been banalized. The economic organization of travel to diffe rent places already guarantees their equivalence. The modernization that has reduced the time involved in traveling has simultaneously reduced the real space through which and to which one can travel. And, as Debord pointed it "while eliminating geographical distance, this society produces a new internal distance in the form of spectacular separation."

After that the TV subtly reminds you the danger in criticize our society : you are against us ? Do you want to live in North Korea ? However, the nature of the commodity reaffirm itself soon after, North Korea is - like any other places and activities - something that must be subjugated to the ever expanding market, we need to shake some hands even here, for business - and pleasure - since the two must become the same unique thing But there still is hope, We all could wake up in the morning and enjoying a simple yet meaningful life. But is this true liberation ? Isn't it a way to distract us from the true solution w ich must be collective ? Isn't this a pass to being lonely and to feel "blue" ?

"At the clothing store nobody tells you the whole world is changing" : everything is said, capitalism don't tell you about the world it is making, you're here to buy as a mindless robot, you don't need to understand that the world is changing, in fact you mustn't; the world is changing by itself, by the forces of the Capital; and no one truly understand how : that's the ultimate "proletarization", proletarization in its essence is the privation of knowledges for a subject and the privation of a subject for knowledges, first we lose the ability to understand what we are producing, but in consequence we now lose the ability to understand what we are consuming, it's a vicious circle, the circle of the commodity. So buy your clothes and become your products, even if the clothes is always changing, seasons by seasons, we are not even able to see it, we are trapped in the phenomena wich do n't allo w us to see the noumena, the Capital instill in us the feeling that we are living in a never ending-present wich always existed and wich will always exist "At the grocery store someone will tell you that what changed is you" : that's the response of the Capital, it's not the world that is changing, it's you, you are the one who is not in phase with the perfect and immuable "present" of the spectacular society, so stop to complain and accept your fate, submit yourself to the system, learn it's rythm or accept that you are excluded from it; and why the grocery store ? Because the control of the spectacle is in the everyday life, in the most basic consumption.

The pants are already forgotten, in this insatiable run for consumption, now we have a new fetish to love : the lamp, a lamp wich is so godly that it can "light the whole darn sky", but only "at 2:pm", never forget that everything is temporal in this world, and again, the Congress could do nothing against it, it c ould not even replicate the modern worship of the commodity, the light became black down there.

Simon is probably the most interesting and intriguing character of this song, he is the double bipolarity of capitalism : he is the worker wich face its own alienation, without meaning in his work he can't "remember anything he've been doing", because of the economic functionnement of capitalism, and perhaps worse, because of the ideological functionnement of capitalism he can't remember "anything he remember", "everything that was directly lived has moved away into a representation" we don't live our own life, we live the life of the Capital by the Capital for the Capital, we are just actors of a stageplay wich was written before we were born, instead of being the actor of our own artwork, we don't have our own memories since we're just travelling from one representation to another. Represented by the graphics behind him, Simon is nothing but a number among other. And the grap hics also indicate us that Simon is also the financial world, the highest abstraction of the Capital, he don't know where he come from, he don't know who he is, is just here doing what he is made to. And there is the dramatical problem : They (the worker and the trader) don't care, as long as they find out what they're - supposed - to do. The "supposed" is the key to understand it fully, supposed according to who ? To what ? To the commodity, we don't think anymore, we don't put ourselves in an historical and ontogenetic approach, we are just here, doing what the God-Capital tell us to do, we become nothing more than a cog in a machinery that depass us all, that kill every bit of liberty in us. Simon IS the system, he is the one that tell us what to do, as showed by the use of "Simon Says", Simon wants to fully become us. He want us to become him. The reward ? A sign on your checks.

Also, the lamp is very sexy."

     not quite
original_html: 6.23.18  6:54 pm   6.22.18  9:34 am   is that the longest question you've ever got or answered?

6.23.18  5:51 pm   6.22.18  5:49 pm well, i'm actually having a problem playing really quickly on guitar. i can play 3rds in a C maj scale (1,3,2,4,(or c,e,d,f) and so on) as 16th notes at 113bpm. but i'm having like a physical problem with my hand.

      i don't know if that's not supposed to happen and I'm holding my guitar weirdly or that's normal and i just need to suck it up and plow through it.

      being alone i'm forced with the latter, but i guess it's not too bad being trapped at 113bpm.

      or should they discover the ways to play  themselves?

html:
5.13.18  10:53 pm   5.13.18  6:03 pm How much of the instrumentation of the song do you usually write in the songwriting process vs. figuring out in the songmaking process? I know you've done randomization for instuments to add? But are there sounds or instrument parts that you sometimes have written out in the "score"?

2.25.18  2:41 pm
embedded answer: https://billwurtz.com/questions/q.php?date=201805131803

5.13.18  6:03 pm   Was the "mountain escape" part of your newest song a fragment that you had stored in your catalog, or did you create while composing the song?

     the video elements were not part of the songwriting process. 'mountain escape plan' is not part of the song. but the bridge of the song ("long gone", etc) was written during the songwriting process


embedded answer: https://billwurtz.com/questions/q.php?date=201802251441

2.25.18  2:41 pm   When you write music do you plan it all out before recording or make it up as you're recording? I get the feeling it's a little of both for you.

     the content is firmly written ahead of time. details as to how to execute it are worked out in the recording session. the lyric/melody, chords, and exact tempo are all firmly established in the writing process, before i even touch the recording. all other instrumental details, such as which sounds to use, and most of the auxiliary instrumental fills and riffs in between the vocals, that would be worked out in the recording process, with some exceptions
original_html:
5.13.18  10:53 pm   5.13.18  6:03 pm How much of the instrumentation of the song do you usually write in the songwriting process vs. figuring out in the songmaking process? I know you've done randomization for instuments to add? But are there sounds or instrument parts that you sometimes have written out in the "score"?

2.25.18  2:41 pm

answers_original.html:

     the video elements were not part of the songwriting process. 'mountain escape plan' is not part of the song. but the bridge of the song ("long gone", etc) was written during the songwriting process

html:
5.13.18  9:47 pm   so like what's the deal with double sharps and double flats in sheet music? i feel like it's just overkill, why not just use the right note? maybe i'm not seeing it in the right light

10.17.17  6:02 pm
embedded answer: https://billwurtz.com/questions/q.php?date=201710171802

10.17.17  6:02 pm   What's the point in using double flats and double sharps when you can just write the note a whole step higher? This has perplexed me for quite a while.

     let's say you are in Gb with a Gb key signature. and you wanna borrow a little minor. it might be easier, to drop a "bb" on the B, rather than trying to put Ab and Anatural next to each other in the scale. if you use Bbb then the scale will flow normally on the page without having to keep flipping the A flat-natural back and forth. but don't take my word for it, try it yourself and see which is more convenient
original_html:
5.13.18  9:47 pm   so like what's the deal with double sharps and double flats in sheet music? i feel like it's just overkill, why not just use the right note? maybe i'm not seeing it in the right light

10.17.17  6:02 pm

answers_original.html:
10.17.17  6:02 pm   What's the point in using double flats and double sharps when you can just write the note a whole step higher? This has perplexed me for quite a while.

     let's say you are in Gb with a Gb key signature. and you wanna borrow a little minor. it might be easier, to drop a "bb" on the B, rather than trying to put Ab and Anatural next to each other in the scale. if you use Bbb then the scale will flow normally on the page without having to keep flipping the A flat-natural back and forth. but don't take my word for it, try it yourself and see which is more convenient

html:
5.6.18  8:57 am   5.4.18  9:04 pm Your 'war on theory' is so weird.  

     Music is just as made up as theory.  

     And you've gotten it wrong anyway.  You're getting theory and convention confused, I guess?  

     Also, the music you make doesn't defy theory in any way, at all, ever.  

     In fact, you very clearly have a theoretical base in Western pop music.  

     Ideas and concepts have been transferred to you, whether through deliberate study or not.  

     And that's okay.  Just let it go.


embedded answer: https://billwurtz.com/questions/q.php?date=201805042104

5.4.18  9:04 pm   Fam do you think knowledge of music theory is neccesary to enjoy and appreciate music?

     other way around

      Do you think people should know more than they generally do about music theory?

     it's all made up anyway, based on the enjoyment and appreciation of music. in fact, music is so wonderful that each time you try to make up some theories, the music turns right around and runs in a different direction, like a game of cat and mouse (the music is the mouse)
original_html:

html:
5.5.18  11:16 pm   5.5.18  4:13 am   I am from the genre police, Starostin Division,

      hello. I would classify your music as Pop Rock, Meta Rock, and maybe Jazz or Folk Rock too, depending on the song. Pop Rock because of your stated hypnotic approach (where every moment is designed to hold interest), and Meta Rock because your music often feels like a parody of music itself (kinda like Ween or Frank Zappa). How would you escape from this classification,

     and why?


embedded answer: https://billwurtz.com/questions/q.php?date=201805050413

html:
5.4.18  12:20 pm   5.3.18  7:41 pm What about doing simple graphics? Don't misunderstand me, I LOVE your videos and I think they've gotten crazier over time, with all the 3D stuff, and movement, and detailed backgrounds, and wild colors etc. But doing simple, more minimalistic videos would let you do more songs at a faster rate, but still have a video to put up for your big youtube audience. Maybe find a balance between doing some wild and crazy videos and doing some videos with that more minimal style (like dont wanna go to school, free to do whatever, jodie foster, diamond, etc.)?

5.3.18  8:52 am   is making a video for every new song really worth it?

     yes, for now

      Right after hotewig you managed to do 4 songs in 4 weeks, and now you've spent a roughly 9 months doing 3 songs+video and 3 short videos. If your goal is to produce as many songs as possible,

     and get them heard

     I think having an accompanying video is the wrong way to go.

     that's what i thought too, in june 2017, but then after 4 songs i realized that the audience simply wasn't there. then i looked at the size of my youtube audience, and it was a no brainer. since then, i've done a video for every song, and it takes much longer, but the music audience (itunes, spotify, even radio) has grown much more since then and continues to steadily grow

     Don't get me wrong I enjoy every femtosecond of your videos but I'd be willing to forgo them if it meant more frequent songs

     i'm considering striking a compromise of perhaps 1 to 1 alternation. but gosh darn the videos are effective. as they say, it's 1982, people hear with their eyes now
original_html: 5.3.18  7:41 pm   5.3.18  8:52 am Why don't you do that thing you did back in 2014, where you had a little spinning disc with the song playing?

answers_original.html:

     yes, for now

      Right after hotewig you managed to do 4 songs in 4 weeks, and now you've spent a roughly 9 months doing 3 songs+video and 3 short videos. If your goal is to produce as many songs as possible,

     and get them heard

     I think having an accompanying video is the wrong way to go.

     that's what i thought too, in june 2017, but then after 4 songs i realized that the audience simply wasn't there. then i looked at the size of my youtube audience, and it was a no brainer. since then, i've done a video for every song, and it takes much longer, but the music audience (itunes, spotify, even radio) has grown much more since then and continues to steadily grow

     Don't get me wrong I enjoy every femtosecond of your videos but I'd be willing to forgo them if it meant more frequent songs

     i'm considering striking a compromise of perhaps 1 to 1 alternation. but gosh darn the videos are effective. as they say, it's 1982, people hear with their eyes now

html:
5.3.18  5:04 pm   5.2.18  9:10 pm Not the asker but that same logic applies to job interviews, right?


embedded answer: https://billwurtz.com/questions/q.php?date=201805022110

5.2.18  9:10 pm   i have an audition for my school band tomorrow. convince me not to be nervous

     you can't deal with nervousness outside of the situation where the nervousness occurs. and to deal with it takes probably a slightly longer amount of time than your audition. this may not seem helpful, but let's say you have 10 auditions. by the 6th one your nervousness will probably be mostly gone. so in that case, it might be a good idea to go for a series of auditions that you don't really want, as practice before going to the one that matters
original_html: 5.3.18  5:04 pm   5.2.18  9:10 pm Not the asker but that same logic applies to job interviews, right?

answers_original.html:
5.2.18  9:10 pm   i have an audition for my school band tomorrow. convince me not to be nervous

     you can't deal with nervousness outside of the situation where the nervousness occurs. and to deal with it takes probably a slightly longer amount of time than your audition. this may not seem helpful, but let's say you have 10 auditions. by the 6th one your nervousness will probably be mostly gone. so in that case, it might be a good idea to go for a series of auditions that you don't really want, as practice before going to the one that matters

html:
5.3.18  1:31 pm   5.1.18  1:35 pm . That's exactly it, I don't where it's coming from. Some quick research on the internet shows that sound bouncing off of objects other than the microphone is picked up by the microphone, causing small interference. I could email you an example of some staticky audio I've recorded if you'd like.

     Anyway, in high quality audio, such as yours,

     when there's silence it's actually silent,

     there's not a little buzz in the background that comes from "sound bouncing off of other objects".

     Apparently solutions are to either get a real high quality microphone,

     or to deck out the room with objects that sound doesn't bounce of, neither of which are in my budget. But you don't seem to have either of those either. So what do you do?


embedded answer: https://billwurtz.com/questions/q.php?date=201805011335

5.1.18  1:35 pm   How can I record quality audio in my room? You don't seem to have any special equipment, you just have a microphone. How can I do the same and not have a terrible static background in my audio?

     where is the static coming from?

html:
5.3.18  5:37 am   Bill, I have travelled far and wide across your website in a quest to consume all the quality content your provide. I keep seeing your answer "graphics free title graphics" pop up too questions about the website format. I was wondering if you could explain this, particularly why you say graphics twice. Thanks Bill, you are great

7.10.17  12:10 pm
embedded answer: https://billwurtz.com/questions/q.php?date=201707101210

7.10.17  12:10 pm   could you explain the phrase "graphics free title graphics" thanks

     it's like you want to make a title for a page, but instead of using any pictures or graphics, you have to just use text. you can use any technique you want, such as different colors, or even rearranging the letters, to make it more interesting while still not using any actual pictures

embedded answer: https://billwurtz.com/questions/q.php?date=201707050049

7.5.17  12:49 am   what time signature is movie star in?

     the chorus/title line has 9 beats in the cycle. it is your choice how to break it up, i hear it as 4/4 + 5/4. the verse uses this figure but does not adhere to it entirely
